messageBody:
I am writing from Bangalore, India where I write lots of code for a
humble living and pray for world peace while I am not coding :-)
I am sorry but I am forced to continue this thread on JUnit which is not
appropriate. I apologize and request to allow me to express myself once
and retreat for ever. No follow up replies from me irrespective of its
intensity.
James, if you wish we can continue this discussion in
computerbooksandauthors as I see this an interesting topic for me to
write a book on “Behavioral trends in changing economic scenarios” !!

In the recent years I have observed a very peculiar behavior from the
professionals in the USA which reminds of those days of Marxism,
Leninism
Just because their jobs are at stake they started to react saying that
their government should adopt protectionist measures without really
admitting that they are no more delivering value for money. Did you ever
think that there were so many talented jobless in other parts of the
world whose talents were not put to good use prior to globalization. If
one advocates the right to equality and right to freedom of
accessibility, one should pursue it till the end and should not change
tones in between.

These countries (India and China) which you are referring to where
criticized by governments in advanced countires for having protectionist
policies and were advised to open up and allow globalization. Now that
these countries are serious about opening up their markets and expect
other countries to reciprocate by allowing them sell what they sell the
best, why all this hue and cry ?!!
While hardware selling is China’s strength, selling software services
is India’s strength partly attributed to its attractive rates.
Shouldn’t we allow others also to sell their expertise or is it written
in the bible that only the USA is privileged to sell its ideas to whole
world.

Excuse me if my tone seems to be abnormal. But that’s the reality and
it bites.

To answer Scotts question, it costs 30 to 40% cheaper taking into
account all hidden costs like travel costs of project managers,
implementation teams, internet connectivity costs etc.

Regards

Rajesh

From: Scott Stirling [mailto:scottstirling@...]
Sent: Sunday, April 06, 2003 11:35 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [offtopic] RE: [junit] The Responsible CIO

> From: James [mailto:jm04469@...]
>
> Working on writing an article for an upcoming issue of
> a magazine targeted towards CIOs. Here is the basic
> thought:
[snip]

I think this post is pretty offtopic. But, you used the word "Agile,"
so, I
read it and am replying.

Interesting article thoughts. Also quite "high level" and speculative,
which made me wonder about some facts.

For instance, what's the typical salary for a senior or principal
developer
in India? How much is their salary affected by whether that engineer is
working out of Bombay or a suburb or some small city? Just curious what
the
CIOs are up against in their decision process -- how much money can be
saved
on a project by outsourcing some of the work? What are the most
successful
ways to leverage outsourcing help?

How much is outsourcing the decision of a CIO? I've seen outsourcing
proposed and advocated at the department Director and VP level, though
the
CIO is usually involved to approve any large IT/Dev expenditure. Of
course
with job title inflation the past few years, there are lots of "CIOs" of
little start-ups too. Anyway, is this typically a decision the CIO
would
really dig into? Or is it a lower level decision just needing financial
approval at the higher level?

I'm curious why we can't get more U.S. people employed in the computer
professions. Every place I've worked in the past few years (including a
couple big time software companies) has had several H1 Visa employees,
usually Indian or Chinese. I've found that these folks vary in their
experience and technical expertise as much as anyone else I've worked
with.

Finally, there's the notion of Agile CIO, which is intriguing. But is
it
just b.s.? I mean, CIOs are high level managers, not developers. How
do
you presume to apply agile methods at the CIO level in more than tenuous
analogies? I think it quite possible the whole notion of CIO is contra
agile methodology.

Scott Stirling
